articles.headline: China’s Software Stalked Uighurs Earlier and More Widely, Researchers Learn
articles.snippet: A new report revealed a broad campaign that targeted Muslims in China and their diaspora in other countries, beginning as early as 2013.
articles.abstract: A new report revealed a broad campaign that targeted Muslims in China and their diaspora in other countries, beginning as early as 2013.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Before the Chinese police hung high-powered surveillance cameras and locked up ethnic minorities by the hundreds of thousands in China’s western region of Xinjiang, China’s hackers went to work building malware, researchers say.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: Trump’s New Russia Problem: Unread Intelligence and Missing Strategy
articles.snippet: High-level clearance is not required to see that the list of Russian aggressions in recent weeks rivals some of the worst days of the Cold War.
articles.abstract: High-level clearance is not required to see that the list of Russian aggressions in recent weeks rivals some of the worst days of the Cold War.
articles.lead_paragraph: The intelligence finding that Russia was most likely paying a bounty for the lives of American soldiers in Afghanistan has evoked a strange silence from President Trump and his top national security officials on the question of what to do about the Kremlin’s wave of aggression.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: City That Once Guided a Nation Now Shows Its Cracks
articles.snippet: Peoria, Ill., was a place where marketers and politicians honed their messages. The pandemic and protests have made clear the sharply different realities of its Black and white residents.
articles.abstract: Peoria, Ill., was a place where marketers and politicians honed their messages. The pandemic and protests have made clear the sharply different realities of its Black and white residents.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ashley Daily Stegall hated how the plywood looked covering the smashed windows at her parents’ jewelry store in Peoria, Ill. So she asked a local artist to paint flowers on the boards. “The goal is to make people happy,” said Ms. Stegall.

articles.headline: In Hong Kong, Arrests and Fear Mark First Day of New Security Law
articles.snippet: Protesters deleted social media accounts, as formerly allowed speech suddenly became a potential crime. The chill over the city has booksellers, professors and nonprofits questioning their future.
articles.abstract: Protesters deleted social media accounts, as formerly allowed speech suddenly became a potential crime. The chill over the city has booksellers, professors and nonprofits questioning their future.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Hong Kong police moved swiftly on Wednesday to enforce China’s new national security rules with the first arrests under the law, as the city immediately felt the chilling effect of Beijing’s offensive to quash dissent in the semiautonomous territory.
articles.byline: By Vivian Wang and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: It’s July 4, but the Firework Shows Won’t Go On
articles.snippet: As many as 80 percent of the holiday fireworks displays in large cities and small towns have been canceled because of the pandemic.
articles.abstract: As many as 80 percent of the holiday fireworks displays in large cities and small towns have been canceled because of the pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: The annual Big Bay Boom over San Diego will be quiet this year. The skies over Lake Tahoe, home to the Lights on the Lake celebration, will be dark.
